Martin: How many gun-control proponents have made these comments? What percentage of the voting public? What percentage of elected officials? You are chasing make-believe boogiemen. As for the politicians who spout the NRA's talking points, I grant you the possibility that their beliefs are sincere but since there are political donations at stake, I think there is a high probability that their beliefs conveniently square with their donors. And George Zimmerman disobeyed the police dispatcher's request. He put himself needlessly into a dangerous situation. He really is the poster child for having a well-trained, law-abiding police force instead of some idiot with a gun.

DWB: If your family member happens to be in that 0.07% statistic, banning or controlling access to the weapon makes a lot of sense.

Think about cars: We restrict who can drive cars by age and skill. Those restrictions don't prevent every death by car. But they help. We restrict driving under the influence. Again, it doesn't stop every death. But it helps. And guess what - with all those restrictions on driving, we haven't banned cars. Nor would the suggestion to ban all cars meet with majority approval.

Good point. Let's look at what we have here. We are desperately in need for improvements in infrastructure. Private companies have no incentive to build the infrastructure we need, but many of them have more than enough cash to pay for it. Investing in infrastructure would create jobs and reduce unemployment. More people at work would increase demand and encourage private companies to spend their cash. Interest rates are historically low.

Am I the only person who thinks that the way to get unstuck is for the government to borrow the money from the private companies and spend it on infrastructure? Of course, borrowing is only one option. We could also get by taxing. How about a "filthy rich" tax? Use it or lose it.

As a small employer myself (though of professionals making far more than Fed min wage), I can tell you that I have just enough staff to perform our current workload.

I hire new staff only when the workload demands it. And when it does I pay the salary I need to pay to hire at the appropriate level.

The alternative would be not hiring and not being able to adequately serve my clients or--even worse--having to turn down new business. So unless it's a very dramatic percentage, an increase in the salary I need to pay makes no difference in hiring decisions.

So, yes--supply and demand still apply, but it's the workload demand that dominates the equation--not some abstract generalizations about "labor market supply and demand".

And you may argue that my experience doesn't scale up to Fortune 500 corporations. But I suspect that they don't maintain more staff than they need for their workload, either. Or that their hiring decisions are driven by anything other than workload demand.

It's actually pretty easy to see why raising the minimum wage does not increase unemployment. Minimum wage is what one pays unskilled labor, including teenagers and less-skilled immigrants. As such, it is the point at which Econ 101 assumptions (closed system with fixed labor flux) do not apply. Raise the minimum age, and part time and summer jobs become more attractive to teens, while unskilled labor jobs are an attractor for immigration--illegal, and to a lesser extent legal immigration; for legal immigrants, the minimum wage is a guarantee that minimizes the financial risk of immigration. It is amazing how many taxi drivers are skilled immigrants who have difficulty finding other jobs. The current lack of minimum wage jobs has temporarily "secured" our southern border, but that will change as the economy improves.
Now, there are situations in which raising the minimum wage would increase unemployment: if there is no possibility for economic expansion, and where the low end of the economic scale is filled with unproductive workers that can be made more productive through fear of losing their jobs, for example. Of course, that circumstance would encourage emigration to parts of the world that provided real opportunities. Fortunately, America is still the land of opportunity; it is our responsibility to keep it that way.

Let illegal immigrants serve 4 years in the military. After their four years is up, they get a green card.

A solution both simple and easy to understand. The military can train them to speak English as well, if necessary.

This program would also work for illegal immigrant children, who through no fault of their own find themselves here.

This allows differentiation from the potentially legal immigrants who can't walk across the border.

Will it?

And even if it does, to what level?

I seem to recall the last minimum wage increase didn't result in any noticeable increase in inflation.

I also seem to recall that pretty much every economic suggestion put forward for the last 4 years has come with a "guarantee" from conservatives that it'll unleash uncontrolled inflation. Still waiting for that to happen...

Absolutely -- this is the fundamental at the core of the issue. Poor people must rely on a paltry local tax base for education dollars, while the better off are educated in the comparative luxury the enclaves' tax base affords.

No other country in the developed world works education funding to give advantage to the already advantaged. It is a level playing field nationwide.

One wonders why, with all the Race to the Top, No Child Left Behind claptrap, no one has ever bothered to mention this glaring fact. It begs the question, as in all other domains in the USA, whether there is any seriousness at all about doing what it takes to save the American exceptional experiment from the banana republic into which it has devolved.

As far as colleges are concerned, we need an end to the college-admissions racket where cadres of self-interested college advisors and admissions offices and PR machines excite students about the schools they should go to and pay for. There are plenty of places where you can get an excellent education without going broke, but the public somehow does not believe it.

The greatest problem, though, is the issue of preferential college admissions. Students worry about the procedures of college admissions without understanding that the true discrimination has taken place in the 18 years before the ever set foot on a college campus. Let us at least make sure that the same amount of public money is spent on all students. So far, every state legislature seems to have failed at this task, making sure that the children of the affluent receive more tax dollars than the children of the poor. Get rid of local funding formulas. Provide at least financial justice for all. Stop discrimination on the basis of wealth.

Very interesting test!

It was interesting to see the different performance -- and the runout in cold weather – and the limitation when few charging nodes are available. A similar situation exists even when they are closely spaced, but perhaps overcrowded by cars – so the rollout of charging infrastructure has to go closely in tandem with the vehicles…. Difficult to manage but critically important.

As it happens, I am also doing a vehicle test-drive experiment -- though not with such a new model. Instead I'm using a Chevy Volt --- (which, as you probably know has electric drive, but also gas/generator backup).

My angle is to see what fraction of regular commuter travel can be powered by solar! If I had a Tesla then it would definitely be nearly 100% because commuters don’t actually travel huge distances in most cases.

Still, I thought you might find it interesting. Some of my data and experiences can be found here:

http://www.rci.rutgers.edu/~dbirnie/Solar2Vehicle/

And, I can be reached by email here: dunbar.birnie@rutgers.edu

"There is no more fundamental premise in all of economics than the statement that a higher price for something will reduce the quantity demanded for that item. Obviously, that applies to labor as well as anything else."

Actually, it's not obvious at all--in fact it would seem obvious only to someone who's never run a business. Anyone's who's had any such responsibility would know that the relationship between labor and productivity bears no resemblance to the relationship of supply and demand for commodities.
It's clear they've influenced his thinking.

Thought the plutocracy numbers only 0.1 per cent, my guess is that the number of affluent Americans numbers close to a fifth of the population just judging by the proportion of cities covered by upper middle class housing.
The professoriate is in the top decile. (Not the sessionals, serfs with doctorates.)
And it seems the allure of private funding is a bit of a corrupting narcotic in economic science.

One of your regular commenters lives in Copenhagen where he reports the minimum wage as $18; in Australia it's $16. Both countries have vibrant unions and working class consciousness in a context of innovative economies.
Canada used to be the same way, althought Vancouver's Fraser Institute was an early harbinger of the effect that a right-wing think tank can have.
There were two great forums of Canadian egalitarian democracy: the hockey arena and the curling rink (adults with brooms slapping inoffensive ice!)
Now, even small-city arenas sport private corporate boxes where they used to have benches where the banker and the house-cleaner once sat side by side.
I was amused to hear Marco Rubio talking about minimum wage workers he knew. Who? His pool cleaner?
In his Audacity of Hope, even Obama rued the fact he spent all his time talking to rich people.

The Good News is that you don't have to take government assistance, like Medicare, or social security. No one can force you to make a claim for benefits. Never make a claim for benefits & you'll be guaranteed not to get any. No gov't employee will come to stuff them into your pocket.

Better yet, you can also continue to buy extra insurance for as long as you like, if you can afford it. Fortunately, the ACA now protects you from all those things your insurance company would surely do to you if ever you got "too expensive." Everything, that is, except jacking up the premiums to "market rates."

On the other hand, if you took advantage of Medicare and social security, all those insurance premiums you've been paying to those insurance scoundrels for 40 years could now be invested in the stock market. Of course, unlike social security, your investment would not be protected from Wall Street scoundrels. :-)

I am sure you always include with your annual  tax return an additional large check payable to the Treasury to reduce the debt.  Sadly, I cannot do that.  We need more people like you and the debt would go away.

All other industrialized countries have some form of universal government run health care, mostly single payor. They get better care as measured by all 16 of the bottom line public health statistics, and they do it at 40% of the cost per person. If our system were as efficient, we would save over $1.5 TRILLION each year.

www.pnhp.org & www.oecd.org, especially
http://www.oecd.org/dataoecd/46/2/38980580.pdf

I turn 65 in a few months. I neither want nor need Medicare and would prefer to be left alone to pay for my own insurance as I have been doing for 40 years. And there are millions like me who don't need government assistance just because they turn 65.
This would not be a solution to the government spending problem but it sure is a good start.

I thumbed you up even though some of the presumptions behind your math are wrong.

For example, you calculated that minimum wage workers work 40 hours a week ... but this is incorrect. Once a minimum wage worker works more than 34 hours a week regularly, then the employer must provide benefits ... such as a vacation (among others such as, formerly, providing healthcare insurance). However, very few minimum wage workers work 34 hours a week; I should know, I used to be a fast food manager.

Indeed, my franchisee often required that I work shifts--under another manager--so we could prevent workers from "regularly" working too many 34 hour workweeks. This was one of my "benefits" as a salaried employee.

Thus, gross pay for just one of the workers cited above would be $12441.00 ... presuming, against the odds, the worker manages to average 33 hours a week over a 52 week year.

Although you are correct in your presumption that not only does the EITC become more efficient when workers work more hours (thereby properly shifting the burden upon employers, as opposed to taxpayers, for their profit-generating employees) while simultaneously increasing tax revenues, your math is still off by $2559.00 ... or nearly two and half months' worth of paychecks.

As a Catholic, I think I can respond to your question.
The church underminded the foundations of those who want to express their beliefs in public view. How can Catholicism serve as a moral authority when so much lying has been done in the name of that 'moral voice'?
I abhor the lies and smear campaigns we see in our politics but I especially despise it when it comes from an institution professing belief in Jesus.
How can a man, woman or church be redeemed if it continually takes solace in the lies it tells itself and others? Redemption is impossible if the lie is vigorous and seeks to defend itself.
I accept the justifiable condemnation of the hierarchy of the church. The bishops say that they have responded to the pederasty within the church but, until they understand and respond to the fact that they are sheltering actual criminals, then they will be relegated to marginal influence within ordinary Catholics' lives. They have to understand that their problems go deeper than what duct tape can repair. Actions, not words, are what is required now. A vigorous investigation where pederasts and those who lie for them go to jail is required.

Unfortunately, the climate created by the Catholic Church for Catholics is that your faith is personal and no institution can be trusted. People want to trust and the bishops have taken it and tossed it in the gutter.

I thought the Catholic Moment started under John XXIII, and if the next pope has his qualities the Church will regain a good deal of influence with those who have left or lapsed.

Sometimes a society needs to change some of its ways, and social conservatism is something to be overcome rather than supported. The New Deal, for example, left segregation basically alone, so it was for the South a powerful synthesis of social conservatism and egalitarian-minded economic policies, and had a great deal of appeal. Segregation was a (perhaps inevitable) ongoing betrayal of our belief in equality before the law, but putting up with it allowed other goals to be reached.

In the same way, the response of the Church to its pederasty problems was the classic socially conservative response when any large institution is threatened -- coverup, legal warfare, payoffs, smear campaigns, and the specialty of the Church, theologically elegant evasions.

Is a Catholic-friendly worldview one that sympathizes with the institutional Church or with Catholics who are alienated from the Church? Sometimes change is needed.

Minimum wage workers generate profits for their employers ... not the taxpayer. It is only morally correct that those receiving the benefits of the employees' labor--the employer--pay all the costs associated with the production of that labor.

As to "teenage employment:" while, certainly, valuable job skills accrue to a subset of this cohort, it is much better for them to work at improving their scholastic skills to enable them to compete more effectively in the global economy.

It should not be the responsibility of teenage workers to put food on the table.
Why not Sweden or Germany?

The era of growth is over. The growth of the past 150 years was fuelled by population growth, technology and abundant and cheap natural resources, especially petroleum. Those days are over. Forever. The 21st century will be an era of limits and contraction. Greece and Spain are the harbingers of the future.

Another point to add - the methods by which people are excluded from reaching the upper classes are somewhat, but not wholly, different from what they have been in the past.  Those who wish to work in finance will find it much easier to get a job with a degree from a prestigious college (a Columbia, a Penn, etc.) than from a good-but-not-elite school (e.g., Syracuse).  Gaining entry to elite colleges is still incredibly restrictive - not via the overtly discriminatory policies of previous eras, but through admissions requirements (not just grades, but extra curricular activities, recommendations, etc.), that make it near impossible for a student from a low-income family (rural or urban, black or white) to gain entry.

Perhaps a hundred years ago, America might have rightly claimed to have been the land of opportunity.........

****************

In 1913 the population of the United States was 97,225,000 - roughly one third of what it is now.

Somewhere along the way the 'upper class' reached enough of a critical mass that membership could be controlled. Perpetuation of class doesn't leave a whole lot of room for new entrants when there are more than enough folks being born with silver spoons in their mouths. The Bush and Kennedy families come to mind. (How many living descendants of Joe and Rose Kennedy are there?) But it's not just politics. Jack Buck was born in the run up to the Great Depression, during which his family reportedly used metal slugs to feed the coin operated gas meter heating their house. How many major sporting events is Jack Buck *not* broadcasting?

It's not necessarily a premeditated kind of thing, much less malicious, and it's not that the upper reaches are actually closed. It's just that once that critical mass was reached it made new blood much less necessary.
Yes; trying to navigate Chatelet with luggage and a looming train or plane departure time induces acute severe depression.

It is sadly true that Toronto's subway is run-down and inefficient. However, when it was built it was just one piece in a coordinated plan to cover the expanding city, linking up with streetcars in the downtown and buses in the periphery. Twenty years ago, it worked quite well, but now, with unbridled city expansion and neglect of the entire system AND traffic gridlock, it has terrible problems, and with the limited creative thought and funds, I see no improvement in sight.

However, in nominating BEST subway systems, I have to put in a word for Barcelona. I was there 2 years ago and it was clean, attractive, easy to navigate, friendly staff, efficient and affordable. The only downside was the number of people who just hang out on the platfrms. I am told a lot of unemployed and possibly homeless people escape bad weather there, but I often felt my purse or backpack was not totally secure.

Other metro systems I have appreciated over the last 20 years (so I am not always up-to-date, I confess) are Munich, Budapest, and Buenos Aires. I love Paris, and the comprehensiveness of the Metro, but last year travelling with luggage via Chatelet and ??? to Gare d'Austerlitz was quite a trial. Too many stairs, everywhere. It may be why Parisians stay slim, but it really did my back in.

I also enjoyed the El in Chicago last spring. It was noisy but had great views, being overground.

Nothing beats graceful aging! I have ridden the tube, in London, over a thirty year period. I love it. My children and grandchildren instinctively know when the computer voice will say, " Mind the gap".
